article.description:
Jeff Myers hit five 3-pointers, matching his career high, and
Richmond overcame a 14-point second-half deficit for a 67-59 victory Tuesday night over a tired Xavier.
article.headline: Spiders beat another ranked team in Xavier
article.linkText: Weary Xavier falls prey to giant-killing Spiders
article.story: CINCINNATI (AP) -- The minutes are piling up and the offense is starting to melt down. Xavier (No. 22 ESPN/USA Today, No. 21 AP) is having a tough time without its senior point guard. Jeff Myers hit five 3-pointers, matching his career high, and Richmond overcame a 14-point second-half deficit for a 67-59 victory Tuesday night over a tired team that faded fast. Senior guard Lionel Chalmers, who broke his foot a week ago, watched helplessly from the bench as Richmond (7-5, 1-0 Atlantic 10) closed with a 15-3 run. "A major factor in the game was Lionel's injury,'' Richmond coach Jerry Wainwright said. "Midseason injuries cause a domino effect, and this was at a very difficult time for their program.'' Xavier (9-4, 0-1) lost Chalmers during a two-point victory over Creighton one week earlier, leaving the Musketeers short-handed at guard. Preseason All-America David West wound up playing 40 minutes against Creighton and 40 minutes again during a seven-point loss Saturday at Alabama. His shooting showed the effects on Tuesday, repeatedly coming up a little short. He had 18 rebounds, but was only 3-of-15 from the field for a season-low 10 points. He also lost his cool in the closing seconds, getting a technical foul for raising his arms while arguing that he had been fouled on an off-target shot. With Chalmers out for four weeks, teams are making things tough on West, who picked up two fouls in the first half and never got into a flow. "They took me out of my game early,'' West said in a low voice. "Right now with this team, if I don't play well, we're not going to win.'' Although Xavier clearly tired down the stretch, missing 13 consecutive shots during Richmond's comeback, the Musketeers didn't want to blame the meltdown on their accumulating minutes. "We really don't have a choice,'' West said. "You just don't want to use that as an excuse -- guys being tired.'' Wainwright used his bench liberally, knowing he could wear down Xavier. "We tried to pressure them on offense and defense, hoping they may get a little fatigued,'' he said. "That was our only chance.'' Richmond also got a subpar game from its top scorer. Mike Skrocki failed to score in the first half and was 2-of-14 from the field, finishing with seven points. Myers led Richmond with 18 points, matching his career high, and Jamaal Scott had 11, including the driving bank shot that put the Spiders ahead to stay with 2:22 left. It was Richmond's first lead since the game's opening minute. With victories over Xavier and Stanford, the Spiders have beaten two ranked teams in a season for the first time since 1990-91. Xavier lost consecutive games for the first time since January 2000. Xavier used its defense to stay ahead for all but the opening minute of the first half. Richmond missed six of its first seven shots against the tight man-to-man pressure. West went to the bench after his second foul and Xavier up by seven in the first half. A 3-pointer by Tim Mayes cut it to 31-28 with 1:49 left, but Xavier closed with a six-point run set up by two traveling calls on the Spiders. Keith Jackson's bank shot made it 37-28 at halftime. Dedrick Finn, who was treated for a leg cramp in the first half, hit a 3-pointer and Anthony Myles followed his own miss for a 14-point lead a minute into the second half. Skrocki, who averages 14.6 points per game, missed his first six shots, but finally scored on a drive to get Richmond's offense rolling and start the comeback. Consecutive 3-pointers by Myers cut it to 48-47 with 12 minutes to go. It was only Xavier's third loss at the Cintas Center, where the Musketeers are 33-3 in three seasons. The other losses were to Massachusetts in the opening season and Cincinnati last season.
